name: Comparative Mythology
description: Discover shared mythological patterns across cultures - flood myths, hero journeys, creation stories, and divine archetypes.
overview: Comparative mythology studies universal patterns, archetypes, and motifs appearing across diverse cultural mythologies. Scholars like Joseph Campbell, Carl Jung, and Mircea Eliade identified recurring themes: the Hero's Journey (monomyth) with departure-initiation-return structure; flood myths from Mesopotamia to Americas; dying and rising gods (Osiris, Jesus, Baldr); cosmic eggs and primordial chaos; world trees/axes connecting realms; trickster figures teaching through transgression; virgin births and miraculous conceptions; and apocalyptic world endings followed by renewal. These patterns suggest either: universal human psychology (Jungian archetypes), common ancestral origins (diffusion), or shared responses to human experience (functionalism).

culturalContext.primarySources: Campbell's Hero with a Thousand Faces, Jung's archetypes, Eliade's comparative religion

sections.title: The Hero's Journey (Monomyth)
sections.body:
Joseph Campbell identified universal pattern in hero myths:

**Departure:** Call to adventure, refusal, supernatural aid, crossing threshold
**Initiation:** Road of trials, meeting goddess/temptress, atonement with father, apotheosis, ultimate boon
**Return:** Refusal of return, magic flight, rescue, crossing return threshold, master of two worlds

Examples: Gilgamesh, Odysseus, Buddha, Jesus, Osiris, Moses, Rama, hero myths globally.

The pattern maps psychological individuation - ego death and rebirth, integration of shadow, achieving wholeness.

sections.title: Universal Flood Myths
sections.body:
Flood narratives appear across cultures:

**Mesopotamian:** Utnapishtim (Gilgamesh), Atrahasis - gods send flood, one man warned, builds ark, repopulates earth
**Biblical:** Noah, Genesis 6-9 - God floods world for wickedness, Noah's ark saves animals/family
**Hindu:** Manu warned by fish (Matsya avatar of Vishnu), survives flood
**Greek:** Deucalion and Pyrrha survive Zeus's flood
**Chinese:** Gun-Yu flood control myth
**Native American:** Various tribes preserve flood stories

Possible origins: ancestral memory of ice age flooding, common psychological symbol of destruction/renewal, or literary diffusion from Mesopotamia.
